description.narrative: Ett resiliens projekt som stöd till 10–19 åriga barn och ungdomar i Syrienkrisen som implementeras av Rädda Barnen och dess partners i Syrien och Libanon. Projektet fokuserar på utbildning, yrkesutbildning, barnskydd, försörjningsmöjligheter, påverkansarbete och fredsbyggande aktiviter. Projektet är 4-årigt (2017-2020) med en uppskattad budget på 75 890 000 SEK. Insatsen inleds med en inceptionsfas november 2017 - mars 2018.

Resilient Adolescents programming in the Syria Crisis covering Lebanon and inside Syria through Save the Children's access points. The programme focuses on education, vocational training, child protection, livelihood, advocacy and peacebuilding.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 4.7 - By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and non-violence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture’s contribution to sustainable development.

4.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla studerande får de kunskaper och färdigheter som behövs för att främja en hållbar utveckling, bland annat genom utbildning för hållbar utveckling och hållbara livsstilar, mänskliga rättigheter, jämställdhet, främjande av en kultur av fred, icke-våld och globalt medborgarskap samt värdesättande av kulturell mångfald och kulturens bidrag till hållbar utveckling.

title.narrative: Save the Children 2017-2020/ Resilient Adolescent Grant Agreement

description.narrative: The theory of change of the programme has been developed by its beneficiaries, stakeholders and partners themselves during a long inception period, extended 2 months, in a very participatory method involving external consultants as facilitators. An extensive conflict sensitivity analysis was produced by Saferworld consultancy to guide the programme in Syria (North-Eastern and South). In depth and participatory needs assessments were conducted then as well. The start of the programme, even beyond the inception phase, consisted mainly in the design of the programme and of the curriculas. A lot of time and efforts were invested as well at that stage for identifying, recruiting and training the implementing partners and programme staff of Save the Children about child's rights programming and other key topics. The intention was to leave sustainably built local capacities behind. This was a laudable effort to ensure relevance, ownership and participation for the activities that Save the Children and its partners implemented afterwards. But it took a generous segment of the programme timeline, while the actual delivery period during which beneficiaries were reached out effectively was quite short, and got even suspended several times due to external factors, out of a 3 and half year activity period. Defining the programme was part of the programme, as agreed by Sida. The first report (2018) was mentioning the support of only a few hundreds beneficiaries, certainly with high quality services, but at a very high cost as well given that the programme is budgeted close to 76 MSEK in total. Save the Children could fortunately accelerate the implementation in 2019, reaching out a larger number of adolescents and care-givers. Save the Children reported that 439 girls and 529 boys attended lifeskills sessions and/or adolescent friendly spaces in Lebanon and in Syria during 2019. For the same period, 216 women and 63 men attended care-givers sessions on positive discipline in parenting. Save the Children's protection case management assisted 97 girls and 105 boys, while 425 adolescents attended a vocational training programme. A follow up field mission was done by Sida in August 2019 in Lebanon which confirmed the relevance and the quality of the services delivered by Save the Children through its local partners. Through a wide set of services, the adolescent, her/his care-givers and even her/his community are offered the opportunity to change positively in a way that ensures significant improvements regarding their well-being and confidence in themselves. Involved adolescents gain a sense of 'agency' that turns them into mature and self-going young persons able to cope with various threats, negative influences, and to grow with their potential and dreams as individuals and within a group of peers and their respective communities. The partners are progressively accompanying recrutees in their self development by providing them with awareness on their situation and on their rights. Key lifeskills are transmitted to them like negotiation skills, problem solving and conflict solving skills, ability to take sound and wise decisions. They learn to mitigate different risks that they may be confronted to like sexual harassment, bullying, sectarian intolerance, enrollment in gangs or militias, consumption of narcotics, etc. They learn how to learn, to write their CV, to prepare a job interview. They acquire IT, social media and language skills. They may develop micro-business initiatives with adequate guidance for developing a business plan, budgeting, accounting, marketing, etc. They may access micro-grants for testing their ideas. At their own initiative, they are supported in implementing community projects, like sanitation campaigns in their neighborhoods, etc. Male and female adolescents are equally targeted, receiving adapted support according to their specific needs and situation in life. Preventing gender-based violence is mainstreamed in the programme. The adolescents are building resilience to the odds and the realities of their daily life which is severely affected by protracted displacement, economic hardship, exclusion, conflicts, violent communities, absence of opportunities, etc. The result is very inspiring. It gained reportedly the total adhesion of the Self-Administration's Ministry of Youth in North Eastern Syria which is one of the main programme stakeholder there.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
